posts.name: Matthew Witmyer
posts.cooked:
Due to some issues we were having at our last competition we would like to try having our drivetrain on one CAN loop and everything else on another one. The problem is that the RoboRIO only has space for one CAN loop to be plugged in, so is there a way to do it with only one RoboRIO? Would it even be worth trying to do it or is the work required going to be harder than itâ€™s worth?

-Matt, Team 2064

Canivore from Cross the Road Electronics does this for you.

The CANivore is a USB-to-CAN device that allows you to add additional CAN FD busses

Price: USD 299.99

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: Keep in mind that the CANivore (today at least) only supports CTRE CAN FD devices - so if you have Falcons and CANcoders youâ€™re set, but if youâ€™re running Spark Maxes those wonâ€™t work.  Also be aware that the CAN FD bus is much pickier about topology than standard CAN.

Correct, I should have mentioned that. REV doesnâ€™t currently have a product for this, but Iâ€™ve heard it is in the works.

I do highly recommend the canivore. Its been a bulletproof product for us this year.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Akash_Rastogi:

Its been a bulletproof product for us this year.

Though your mileage may vary.  I understand that 2992â€™s drivetrain issues this past weekend at Magnolia were linked to the CANivore.

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked: Also please note that CAN should never be wired as a loop.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: TBH, CAN FD is nice and all, but all I really need is a second, standard CAN bus like on the RIO for most things. Cross-compatibility and more flexible topologies is more useful than higher speeds for the vast majority of applications IMO.

Thatâ€™s literally the first instance Iâ€™ve ever heard of someone claiming their issues stemmed from a canivore. Unfortunate for them, but sounds out of the ordinary.

The only thing we changed out of the box was switched to a 90 degree USB C cable which can be better held in and strain relieved.

beedward:

the CAN FD bus is much pickier about topology than standard CAN .

I hear this but havenâ€™t really experienced it being worse. My team runs 13 can devices on a canivore. Every single one of them connects in parallel off a separate 12 inch branch (star topology) . We have a rock solid can connection that hasnâ€™t dropped in 2 years.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
What were some of the issues you were having?

We always wire the important components up first. Drivetrain, then low, protected components (elevator motors, Pneumatic control module, etc, then wire the exposed components last

This year we are trying something different with termination, where we have 1 half termination (RoboRIO), then 2x 1/4 terminations (240 Ohm), one before going up our arm, one at the end of our arm

That way, if our arm gets caught and rips the CAN bus apart, it will be mostly terminated and still will be able to communicate with the drivetrain

This has already saved us in one match

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: We use a CANivore exactly this way, to keep the drive train on itâ€™s own CAN loop separate from the rest of the motors and encoders. It not only creates redundancy, it also helps with CAN utilization.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: Quick question, is it true that you canâ€™t check can utilization on the CANivore during a match on the dashboard?

posts.name: Matthew Witmyer
posts.cooked: The main issue we were having was our elevator pulling out a CAN loop and therefore everything going out and us being dead in the water. Maybe there is a better way to wire it instead. Also we do use SparkMAXs so unfortunately the CANivore wont work for us.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: You could wire those specific motors with pwm. Thus if they get ripped out the can network stays intact.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
cbale2000:

CAN FD is nice and all, but all I really need is a second, standard CAN bus like on the RIO

See R714 and R718.  While it doesnâ€™t explicitly say that no other CAN busses [added: that is, other than the controlling RIO and the CANivore] are legal, it seems implicit. Italics indicates blue box info.

R714 *Control CAN motor controllers from the roboRIO. Each CAN motor controller must be controlled with signal inputs sourced from the roboRIO and passed via either a PWM (wired per R713) or CAN bus (either directly or daisy-chained via another CAN bus device) signal, but both shall not be wired simultaneously on the same device. As long as the CAN bus is wired legally so that the heartbeat from the roboRIO is maintained, all closed loop control features of the CAN motor controller may be used. (That is, commands originating from the roboRIO to configure, enable, and specify an operating point for all CAN motor controller closed loop modes fit the intent of R701).  â€œWired directlyâ€ includes via any series of PASSIVE CONDUCTORS (i.e. star or hub configurations using only PASSIVE CONDUCTORS are permitted.)

R718 *USB to CAN adapter permitted. Additional CAN bus connections may be added to the roboRIO using the CTR Electronics CANivoreTM P/N 21-678682 USB-to- CAN adapter. Any additional CAN bus added in this manner satisfies the requirements of R714 (i.e. you may connect motor controllers to this additional bus).

Some possible suggestions:

Instead of running the can bus up and then down the elevator, end the can bus at the top so that there is only one can run on the elevator. (From @beedward - and put your terminating resistor just before the elevator run)

Run some rope alongside the can wire with the rope cut shorter than the can wire so in case something extends too far, the rope has force put on it, but the can wires are safe.

Wire the can wire going to the elevator separately to everything else and plug it in in parallel. This is more finicky and you may need a second terminating resistor at the top.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: IMO anything other than exactly two 120 ohm terminators will make things worse.    The RIO has one that canâ€™t be turned off, so you should add exactly one to your bus.   Usually thatâ€™s in the PDP/PDH but it could be somewhere else. Using standard CAN it would be OK I think to run a branch up your elevator, unterminated, and put the terminator elsewhere. Using different termination (two 240s plus the RIOâ€™s 120) is not a great idea, since neither 240 ohm really does any reflection suppression since it still looks like a discontinuity to the bus. I would put a 120 ohm before the point where you think your CAN bus will rip out and not worry about reflections on the elevator line.  Or try to make it so your CAN bus doesnâ€™t rip outâ€¦ But as Iâ€™ve said before, standard CAN is somewhat forgiving.  FRC robots generally arenâ€™t using anywhere close to the max length, where having the terminator at the end of the line really matters.  Having the total termination as 60 ohms  (two 120s in parallel) matters a lot more. But I maintain - CAN FD is a different story!!  12" is the max stub I would suggest and I am surprised itâ€™s been working for you with a star topology.  I would not recommend that any team try that.  Is it worth the cleaner wiring to risk potential issues on the field?

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: I do wish someone (REV?) would come out with a CANivore-type device that created a second standard CAN bus.  It would allow those of us running NEOs to take advantage of the benefits of separating our drivetrain from everything else.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
As far as Iâ€™m aware, itâ€™s not possible to use only a CANivore, you wouldnâ€™t be able to connect a PDP (which I believe is required) or a pneumatic controller as even the CTRE ones arenâ€™t CAN FD capable. CANivore, as far as I know, isnâ€™t meant to replace the RIOâ€™s CAN network, but rather to augment it to avoid network bandwidth limitations. Any use of a CANivore on a FIRST robot inherently means youâ€™re using multiple CAN networks.

My complaint isnâ€™t about the CANivore in principle, per say, but simply that it doesnâ€™t (currently, at least) support a more standard-speed network thatâ€™s compatible with standard FIRST controllers from other brands.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
Akash_Rastogi:

Correct, I should have mentioned that. REV doesnâ€™t currently have a product for this, but Iâ€™ve heard it is in the works.

I believe said device is functionality that SPARK MAXes should already be able to handle, there just needs to be software support including NI making some minor changes to the roboRIO kernel.
